metadata.title: Artificial neural network optimization for methyl orange adsorption onto polyaniline nano-adsorbent: Kinetic, isotherm and thermodynamic studies

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Artificial neural network optimization formethyl orange adsorption onto polyaniline nano-adsorbent: Kinetic, isotherm and thermodynamic studies
Marjan Tanzifi a,⁎, SeyyedHosseinHosseini a, AsiehDehghani Kiadehi b,Martin Olazar c, Kianoush Karimipour a, Reza Rezaiemehr a, Imran Ali d,⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Ilam, Ilam, Iran b Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran c Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Basque Country, Bilbao, Spain d Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia (Central University), New Delhi 110025, India
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: drimran.chiral@gmail.com, drimran
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2017.08.122 0167-7322/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 August 2017 Received in revised form 28 August 2017 Accepted 30 August 2017 Available online xxxx
This study aims to synthesize a polyaniline nano-adsorbent and use it to adsorb methyl orange dye from the aqueous solution. The averageparticle size of nano-adsorbentwas about 70nm. The effects of various parameters have been analysed, as are pH, temperature, adsorption time, initial concentration and adsorbent dosage, and they were optimized by an artificial neural network model. The multilayer feed forward neural network with five inputs and one output has been trained with eight neurons in the hidden layer. A comparison of the experimental datawith the dye adsorption efficiency predicted by the artificial neural networkmodel showed that this model can estimate the behavior of the adsorption process of methyl orange dye on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent under different conditions. The study yielded the result that dye adsorption capacity of the nano-adsorbent increased from 3.34 to 32.04 mg/g and from 3.28 to 30.28 mg/g as the dye initial concentration was increased from 10 to 100 mg/L, at 65 °C and 25 °C, respectively. Also, dye adsorption equilibrium was achieved in 60 min for methyl orange dye. The adsorption kinetics was studied based on pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second-order, intraparticle diffusion and Elovich models. The results showed that the adsorption data at all levels of initial concentration have the best consistency with the pseudo-second order equation. Furthermore, two-parameter isotherm models (Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin) and three-parameter isotherm models (Hill, Sips and R-P) were used to ascertain the nature of the adsorption isotherm. Based on this study, the maximum adsorption capacity was estimated to be 75.9 mg/g. Thermodynamic studies indicated that methyl orange dye adsorption was endothermic on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Artificial neural network Isotherm Kinetic Methyl Orange Polyaniline nano-adsorbent Thermodynamic

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Many factories and industries, such as textile, paper making, food processing, leather, and plastics and rubber use synthetic organic dyes in their various processes. The dyes discharged into the environment through wastewater have undesirable effects on living organisms [1, 2]. This material is toxic and hazardous and can cause irreparable illnesses and diseases, such as cancer and genetic mutation in humans and other creatures [3,4]. Therefore, thedyesmust be removed fromdifferent industrial wastewaters in order to prevent various possible damages to living organisms and to reduce soil and water pollution.
Over the years, severalmethods have been used to conduct dye containingwastewater treatment, as are photocatalytic degradation of dyes
_ali@yahoo.com (I. Ali).
[5], nanofiltration [6], degradation of dyes with microorganisms [7] and adsorption [8–12]. Due to lower prices, simpler design and operation, and high dye removal efficiency, the adsorption process is highly considered compared to othermethods ofwater andwastewater treatment [13,14]. Recently, several adsorbents have been used for removing dyes fromwater and wastewater, as are activated carbon produced by chitosan flakes for removal ofmethylene blue dye [15], iron composite nanoparticles for uptake of congo red dye [3], waste pea shells for removal of malachite green [1],polyaniline/titanium dioxide nanocomposite and polypyrrole/titanium dioxide nanocomposite in the removal of congo red dye [16], TLAC/Chitosan composite for removal of crystal Violet [17], polyacrylonitrile/activated carbon composite for removal of acid Yellow 99 [18] and Hexagonal shaped nanoporous carbon for adsorption of methyl orange [19].
One of the most important conductive polymers is polyaniline, which hasmany advantages, such as low cost, ease of synthesis, stability
against air and moisture and high efficiency for the removal of pollutants [20,21]. This conductive polymer has wide applications in various fields including anti-corrosion coatings [22], sensors and biosensors [23], supercapacitors [24] and also the removal of various pollutants from water and wastewater [25,26].
Methyl orange dye is regarded as one of the harmful dyes for aquatic ecosystems and human life [27]. Robati et al. used graphene oxide for the simultaneous removal of methyl orange dyes and BR-12 from the aqueous phase. This study analysed the effect of various parameters, such as pH, adsorption time, initial concentration of dye solution and temperature. The optimum time for the adsorption process is 100 min and themaximumadsorption capacity ofmethyl orange dye is obtained at pH = 3, 16.83 mg/g [28]. Furthermore, Haldorai et al. used chitosan/ MgO composite for removing methyl orange dye. In their study, the maximum adsorption capacity was calculated as 60 mg/g [29].
The artificial neural network (ANN) is regarded as one of the most powerful tools to predict the adsorption process [30], which is rarely used to model the process of dye adsorption from water and wastewater. Ghaedi et al. used artificial neural networks to predict the adsorption of methyl orange dye by gold nanoparticles loaded on activated carbon and Tamarisk. They studied and modeled the effect of four parameters, namely, initial concentration of dye solution, adsorbent dosage, contact time and stirrer speed, on the efficiency of dye adsorption. A comparison between the experimental results with the adsorption efficiency predicted by artificial neural networks indicated that the artificial neural network is a suitable predictor to estimate the behavior of methyl orange dye adsorption on gold nanoparticles loaded on activated carbon and Tamarisk under different experimental conditions [31].
In the present study, artificial neural networks were used to predict methyl orange dye adsorption on polyaniline nano-adsorbent. The effect of five parameters, i.e., pH, adsorbent dosage, adsorption time, initial concentration of dye solution and temperature, on the efficiency of methyl orange dye adsorption was analysed, and the data were modeled using artificial neural networks. Moreover, kinetics, isotherms and thermodynamics of methyl orange dye adsorption on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent were studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The materials used in this study include aniline monomer, ammonium peroxodisulfate, sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate, sulfuric acid, sodium hydroxide and methyl orange pigments, which are all laboratory products bought fromMerck Company in Germany. Prior to the synthesis process, aniline monomer was distilled once. The deionized distilled water was used to wash and prepare the acid, alkali and dye solutions.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of polyanilinenano-adsorbent
sections.text:
In order to prepare the polyaniline nano-adsorbent, 2.5 g ammonium peroxodisulfate oxidant were added to 25 mL of distilled water and the solution was stirred by a magnetic stirrer for 15 min. Then, the solution containing the stabilizer, i.e., 0.4 g of sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate in 25 mL of distilled water, was added to the solution. Subsequent to 15 min, 50 mL of 2 M sulfuric acid solution were added to the solution in order to reach a final volume of 100 mL. The solution was stirred for 15 min with a magnetic stirrer. In the next step, 1 mL of once-distilled aniline monomer was added to the solution drop by drop. By adding aniline monomer, the solution color changed indicating the beginning of the polymerization. After 5 h, the final solution was filtered, and the polymer was then rinsed several times by distilled water and dried in an oven at 40 °C in order to remove oligomers and impurities in the synthesized polymer. Finally, the
polymer was powdered in order to be used as a sorbent for methyl orange dye adsorption.

sections.heading: 2.3. Methyl orange dye adsorption runs
sections.text:
A studywas conducted on the effect various parameter, namely, pH, adsorbent dosage, temperature, initial concentration of dye solution and adsorption time, have on the efficiency of methyl orange dye adsorption on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. The ranges analysed of pH, adsorbent dosage, temperature, initial concentration of solution and adsorption time were 2–10, 0.02–0.15 g, 25–65 °C, 10–100 mg/L and 1–60 min, respectively. Furthermore, the volume of dye solution in all experiments was 50 mL and the stirring speed 1200 rpm. Sulfuric acid solution and sodium hydroxide solution were used to change the dye solution pH. Visible light spectroscopy at a maximum wavelength of 464 nmwas used to measure the dye concentration. In order to calibrate the device, a number of standard samples with concentrations of 0.25–10mg/Lwere prepared and adsorption values for each concentration were measured by the device. Using the values of the standard solution concentration and their corresponding adsorption values, a calibration line was drawn. In each experiment, 50 mL of dye solution of given initial concentration, pH and temperature were stirred and a certain amount of adsorbent was added. The solution was stirred for the time required for dye adsorption. The resulting solutionwas filtered and the final concentration wasmeasured by visible light spectroscopy. Dye adsorption efficiency was calculated by the following equation:
%ð Þ ¼ Ci−Cf Ci 100 ð1Þ
where Ci and Cf (mg/L) are the initial concentration of dye solution, and after the adsorption process, respectively.
Furthermore, qe and qt (mg/g) are the amount of methyl orange dye adsorbed on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent in equilibrium and at time t, respectively, which are obtained by the following equations:
qt ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ V m
ð2Þ
qe ¼ Ci−Ceð Þ V m
ð3Þ
where, Ce (mg/L) is the concentration of methyl orange dye in equilibrium and Ct (mg/L) the concentration of methyl orange dye at time t.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphology and chemical structure of the nano-adsorbent
sections.text:
The morphology of the synthesized nano-adsorbent was studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM). Fig. 1a and b show the SEM images of the pure polyaniline and the polyaniline nano-adsorbent, respectively. As observed, the pure polyaniline is made up large size particles with an agglomerated structure, while the polyaniline nanoadsorbent has size-uniform 70 nm particles. The presence of sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate in the synthesized environment caused the generated nano-particles to be small. Stabilizers can generate chemical binding with the polymer or can be physically absorbed by polymer chains, and so they do not allow an excessive growth of the polymer chains. As a result, they prevent the aggregation of particles during polymerization and products with more uniform and smaller particles are formed. The smaller size of the particle increases the contact area, thus increasing the efficiency of pollutant adsorption. Fig. 1c shows the SEM images of the polyaniline nano-adsorbent after methyl orange adsorption. As observed the adsorbent surface has changed and particles are stuck together and their pores filled.
The chemical structure of the synthesized nano-adsorbentwas studied by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR). The FTIR spectrum of polyaniline nano-adsorbent is shown in Fig. 2. As observed in the figure, peaks at wavelengths of 1558, 1475, 1299, 1121, 800 cm−1 are related to C_C stretching vibration of the quinoid ring, stretching vibration of C_C of the benzenoid ring, C\\N stretching vibration, C\\H in-plane deformation and C\\H out-of-plane deformation, respectively.
The BET method was used to evaluate surface properties of the polyanilinenano-adsorbent bynitrogen adsorption-desorption. Pore diameter and specific surface area were calculated by the mentioned method. Furthermore, pore volume and their size distributionwere calculated by BJH method. Based on this method and applying monolayer or multilayer adsorption theories, nitrogen adsorption volume and gas-solid surface are determined in the ranges considered for the pore sizes. Fig. 3a and b, respectively, show the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms andpore size distribution curves calculated by BJHmethod, for the polyaniline nano-adsorbent.
In addition, the values of three parameters (specific surface area, total pore volume and pore diameter) are listed in Table 1 for the polyaniline nano-adsorbent and the pure polyaniline. As observed in the table, specific surface area and total pore volume of the polyaniline nano-adsorbent are larger than those for pure polyaniline.
3.2. Artificial neural networks
Artificial neural networks are computermodels established based on simplifiedmodels of human brain biological activities, such as the ability to learn, think, remember and solve problems. Neural network models consist of neurons and weights and they are based on the assumption that a continuous system of simple processing elements can learn complex relationships between independent and dependent variables [32]. It is not easy to develop a neural network model, as it includes the following steps: selection of data, data processing, selection of the neural network structure, selection of network training algorithm, network training, trained neural network testing and using trained neural network for validation and simulation [33].
The neural network consists of a joint structure including an input layer, an intermediate layer (known as hidden layer) and an output layer. Each layer consists of simple processing elements called neurons. Neurons communicate layers via weight adjusted signals. The input layer receives signals from external sources. Weighting for each input is conducted separately in this layer and these data are sent for processing to the hidden layer [34]. Hidden layers performed the preprocessing and the results are transferred into other hidden layers and output layers using transfer functions [32]. In the feed forward neural network, data are only moved forward in one direction. In this study, 60% of 48 data were used for education and development of the neural network and 20% were excluded and used for simulation.
Adsorption time, pH, temperature, initial concentrations and the amount of nano-adsorbent were defined as input data for the model, and adsorption efficiency data were inserted and defined as output. The experimental data are listed in Table 2.
As mentioned above, the data were divided into three categories, namely, training, validation and testing. 60% of the data were used for training, 20% for validation and 20% for testing. In the neural network architecture built in this study, the number of neurons in the input layer is
5, i.e., the same as the input variables of the model, and 8 in the hidden layer. There is only one neuron in the output layer, which is the removal rate. Fig. 4 shows the network structure with the three layers.
The network performance is evaluated based on the fit of the experimental data and the prediction accuracy of the models used, according to the Mean Square Error (MSE) and the correlation coefficient (R2):
MSE ¼ P qexp−qcal =qexp 100
N ð4Þ
Different amounts of neurons were tested for the inner layer and 8 neurons was the optimum value of highest correlation coefficient and
least Mean Square Error. The results of the model were compared with experimental data and the impact of each one of the five factors on the adsorption efficiency was analysed. It should be noted that the data used for comparison have not been used in the training, and a correct prediction means therefore that the network is reliable and usable.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of pH
sections.text:
The effect the pH solution has on the methyl orange dye adsorption by polyaniline nano-adsorbent was studied in an initial pH range of 2– 10. Fig. 5a shows the effect pH has on the adsorption efficiency. As observed, the polyaniline nano-adsorbent has a high potential for methyl orange dye adsorption, over the pH range of 6–10. In addition, with the decrease of pH from 6 to 2, the adsorption efficiency decreased from 90% to 64.5%. The charge state of methyl orange dye is affected by pH of solution. In the pH b 6, a positive charge can be generated on a nitrogen of methyl orange ion. Therefore, with decrease of pH of solution, the electrostatic attraction between methyl orange dye and polyaniline nano-adsorbent would be weak and adsorption efficiency decrease [35]. The highest methyl orange adsorption efficiency on
polyaniline nano-adsorbent was 98.17% at 10 pH. In view of Fig. 5a, the results predicted by the ANNmodel are consistent with the experimental data.
3.4. Effect of nano-adsorbent dosage on the adsorption efficiency
The effect the dosage of polyaniline nano-adsorbent (0.02– 0.15 g/50 mL) has on the adsorption of methyl orange dye (30 mg/L) was analysed. The adsorption efficiency increased as the amount of polyaniline nano-adsorbent was increased and reaches a maximum value of 99% at 0.15 g for methyl orange dye. This may be related to the higher accessibility to the adsorption sites due to the higher amount of polyaniline nano-adsorbent. Thus, as the ratio of nano-adsorbent to methyl orange dye was higher, the adsorption process onto the nano-
Fig. 5. Effect of (a) pH (b) adsorbent dosage and (c) adsorption time
adsorbent surface was faster and reached a higher extent, leading to a lower dye concentration in the solution. The experimental data and outputs obtained using the ANN model for the adsorbent dosage is shown in Fig. 5b. It is observed that the ANN model provides reasonably good predictions of dye adsorption efficiency.
3.5. Effect of adsorption time on the adsorption efficiency
Fig. 5c shows a comparison of the dye adsorption efficiency predicted by the ANN model with the experimental data of adsorption with time. As observed, the ANN model suitably predicts the dye adsorption efficiency. It is clear from thefigure that dye adsorption equilibriumwas achieved in 60 min for methyl orange dye. The figure shows that there are three stages in the dye adsorption process. At the first and second
on dye adsorption efficiency (experimental and predicted data).
stages, the initial dye adsorption is fast (within 3 min and 3–10 min), and subsequently the process is slow in the range of 10–60 min.

sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of dye initial concentration on the adsorption capacity
sections.text: The experiments were conducted using different concentrations of methyl orange dye solutions under the specified optimum nano-adsorbent dosage, pH and adsorption time. The impact of dye initial concentration on dye adsorption capacity was investigated in the range of 10– 100 mg/L and the results are shown in Fig. 6. As observed, the dye adsorption capacity of the polyaniline nano-adsorbent increased from 3.34 to 32.04 mg/g and from 3.28 to 30.28 mg/g as the dye initial concentration was increased from 10 to 100 mg/L, at 65 °C and 25 °C, respectively. It is observed that the ANN model performs well on predicting the dye adsorption capacity. In addition, the ANN showed the potential of application to predict the adsorption experimental data with high accuracy for wide range of experimental condition (Fig. 7).

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The prediction of adsorption rate is an essential aspect for the design of any adsorption system, as it allows determining the optimumadsorption time. Accordingly, the adsorption rate of the adsorbate (methyl orange dye) on the nano-adsorbent (polyaniline) has been monitored. The kinetic models tried are as follows: pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second-order, intraparticle diffusion and the one by Elovich, with the parameters being calculated for each model. 50 mL of dye solution with an initial concentration of 30, 50 and 100 mg/L at pH 10 were used in order to determine the kinetic adsorption of methyl orange dye on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. Adsorbent dosage and adsorption time were 0.15 g and 1 to 60 min, respectively.
3.8. Pseudo-first-order kinetic model
The pseudo-first-order kinetic model was proposed by Lagergren in 1898 and explains the adsorption process of solid-liquid systems based on adsorption capacity. This model assumes that the rate of adsorbate uptake (methyl orange) with time is proportional to the driving force (difference between equilibrium adsorption capacity and the amount adsorbed) [36]. It is also assumed that the rate of occupation of adsorption sites is proportional to the number of unoccupied sites. According to this model, physical adsorption is the prevailing process (weak interaction between the adsorbate and adsorbent surface). The non-linear form of the pseudo-first-order equation is as follows:
qt ¼ qe−qee−k1t ð5Þ
In this equation, qe and qt (mg/g) are the amounts of methyl orange dye adsorbed by the nano-adsorbent in equilibrium and at time t, respectively, and K1(1/min) is the pseudo-first-order rate constant. The constants of this model (qe and K1) were obtained by plotting log(qe−qt) versus t for the three initial concentrations of 30, 50 and 100 mg/L, Fig. 8a, and their values are shown in Table 3. The correlation coefficients for the concentrations of 30, 50 and 100 mg/L, are 0.7137, 0.8635 and 0.9142, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.9. Pseudo-second-order kinetic model
sections.text:
According to the pseudo-second-order kinetic model, chemical adsorption is the prevailing process, and the rate of occupation of adsorption sites is proportional to the square of the number of unoccupied sites. The kinetic equation is as follows [37]:
qt ¼ K2qe2t
1þ K2qet ð6Þ
where K2 (g/mg·min) is rate constant of the pseudo-second-order kinetic model. The values of qe and K2 are obtained using plot of qt versus t, summarized in Table 3. Fig. 8b shows the plot of pseudo-second-order kinetic model, which has correlation coefficient 0.9091, 0.9447 and 0.9395 for the initial concentrations of 30, 50 and 100 mg/L, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.10. Intraparticle diffusion kinetic model
sections.text:
The adsorption mechanism of an adsorbate on a porous adsorbent occurs according to the following three steps: Mass transfer to the
tal and predicted data) (a) temperature 65 °C (b) temperature 25 °C.
surfaceof the adsorbent, intraparticle diffusion and adsorption reactions on the adsorption sites in the adsorbent [38].
The intraparticle diffusion model was used to verify whether intraparticle diffusion was a rate-controlling step or not in the process of adsorption of methyl orange on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. The intraparticle diffusion kinetic equation by Weber and Morris is as follows [39]:
qt ¼ Kid tð Þ0:5 þ C ð7Þ
where Kid (mg/g·(min)1/2) indicates intraparticle diffusion rate constant. C is a constant related to the thickness of the boundary layer. A high value of C means a high impact of the boundary layer on the molecular diffusion. Fig. 8c shows the plot of the intraparticle diffusion kinetic model for the adsorption of methyl orange on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent for different dye initial concentrations. Figure shows three steps with different slopes for all initial concentrations. The constant of intraparticle diffusion (Kid and C) for all steps are presented in Table 3. As can be seen, dye molecules diffuse into adsorbent particles and then diffuse into its macropore at the start of the adsorption process.
Subsequently, methyl orange molecules diffuse into polyaniline micropores. Then, the equilibrium condition in adsorption process occurs.

sections.heading: 3.11. Elovich kinetic model
sections.text:
Elovich kinetic model was first presented by Roginsky and Zeldovich [40,41]. In recent years, the model was used to study the process of adsorption of pollutants and adsorbates from water and wastewater [42,43]. Elovich equation is generally used for chemical adsorption kinetics. The linearized equation of the model is as follows:
qt ¼ 1 β ln αβð Þ þ 1 β ln tð Þ ð8Þ
where α(mg/g·min) and β(g/mg) are the initial rates of adsorption and desorption, respectively. Constant β is related to the extent of surface coverage and chemisorption activation energy [44]. Elovich equation constants were obtained from the slope and intercept of qt versus Ln (t) plot and are shown for different
initial concentrations in Table 3. Elovich kinetics plots for methyl orange dye adsorption on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent are shown in Fig. 8d. The correlation coefficient for the initial concentrations of 30, 50 and 100 mg/L are 0.9021, 0.8815 and 0.8469, respectively.
The results obtained from the kinetic study show that the experimental data are well described by the pseudo-second-order kinetic model, which is evidence that the process of methyl orange adsorption onto the polyaniline nano-adsorbent is chemisorption-controlled. Furthermore, the methyl orange adsorption capacity on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent obtained through the pseudo-second-order kinetic model is very close to the experimental value.

sections.heading: 3.12. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text: Adsorption isotherms describe the relationship between the amount of methyl orange dye adsorbed on the polyaniline nanoadsorbent and the equilibrium concentration of the dye solution after adsorption at a certain temperature and pH. In this study, two-parameter isotherm models (Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin) and three-parameter isotherm models (Sips, Hill and Redlich-Peterson) were used to model the adsorption of methyl orange dye on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent.

sections.heading: 3.13. Two-parameter isotherms
sections.text:
The Langmuirmodel is one of themost common two-parameter isotherms, which is used to evaluate the adsorption on a variety of adsorbents. This two-parameter model is based on the assumption that the process of adsorption of the adsorbate (methyl orange) is carried out on homogeneous sites on the adsorbent surface (polyaniline nano-adsorbent). In addition, according to thismodel, adsorption energy is independent of surface coverage.
According to the Langmuir model, all sites are similar to each other and each adsorption site can only adsorb one species. In addition, the adsorption process is carried out in monolayer [45,46]. The Langmuir
isotherm equation is as follows:
qe ¼ qmKLCe 1þ KLCe ð9Þ
In this equation, qe, Ce, qm and KL (L/mg) are the amount of adsorbed methyl orange dye for a certain amount of polyaniline nano-adsorbent (mg/g), the concentration of dye solution in equilibrium (mg/L), the maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g) and the Langmuir equilibrium constant, respectively. Fig. 9a shows the Langmuir isotherm plot for the adsorption ofmethyl orange dye on thepolyaniline nano-adsorbent. The values obtained for Langmuir equation parameters and correlation coefficients are listed in Table 4.
Themain feature of the Langmuir isotherm is a parameter called the separation factor (RL), which is calculated by the following equation:
RL ¼ 11þ KLci ð10Þ
where Ci is initial concentration of methyl orange dye. The value of separation factor indicates the isotherm type. Thus, RL N 1 unfavorable, RL=1 linear, 0 b RL b 1 favourable and RL=0 irreversible. The values of RL are shown in Table 4. As observed, separation factor is in the 0–1 range, which is evidence that methyl orange dye adsorption on polyanilinenano-adsorbent is a favourable process.
The Freundlich isotherm is a purely empirical equation based on the adsorption on a heterogeneous surface with adsorption sites being exponentially distributed with respect to adsorption energy. According to this equation, adsorption is carried out in multilayer. This equation does not predict the maximum adsorption capacity. Freundlich isotherm equation is expressed as follows [47]:
qe ¼ KF Ceð Þ 1=n ð11Þ
where KF((mg/g)·(L/mg)1/n) is the Freundlich isotherm constant indicating the ability of methyl orange dye adhesion on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. Another parameter of the equation is 1/n, which is
the intensity of adsorption. These two parameters were obtained by drawing Freundlich plot, Fig. 9a, and their values as well as the correlation coefficient of the fitting are shown in Table 4. If 1/n is b1, the process of methyl orange dye adsorption on the polyaniline nanoadsorbent is favourable. If 1/n moves towards zero, the adsorbent surface is more heterogeneous and the adsorption isotherm takes a nonlinear trend. And, if 1/n is N1, adsorption is unfavourable.
The Temkin model is based on an empirical equation that contains a factor indicating the interactions between the adsorbent (polyaniline nano-sorbate) and the adsorbate (methyl orange). This equation is defined based on chemical adsorption, and assumes that heats of adsorption are reduced linearly due to the interaction of adsorbent and adsorbate in different layers of adsorption for all the molecules [48].
Temkin isotherm equation is as follows [49]:
qe ¼ B ln KTð Þ þ Bln Ceð Þ ð12Þ
where B= RTb is a constant related to the heat of the adsorption process. KT is the equilibrium binding constant of Temkin isotherm, which is related to the maximum adsorption energy. b [(J/mol)·(g/mg)], R and T are the Temkin isotherm constant, the universal gas constant 8.314 J/mol·K and the absolute temperature (in Kelvin), respectively. The parameters of this equation are obtained from qeversus ln (Ce) plot (Fig. 9b) and are summarized in Table 4.
aniline nano-adsorbent (pH, temperature, amount of adsorbent and adsorption time,were

sections.heading: 3.14. Three-parameter isotherms
sections.text:
The three-parameter Hill isotherm shows the connection of different species on the homogeneous surfaces. Based on this model, adsorption is a cooperative phenomenon with the ligand binding ability at one site on the macromolecule and various binding sites on the same macromolecule. Hill equation is as follows [50]:
qe ¼ qHCe
n
KD þ Cen ð13Þ
where n and KD are Hill isotherm constants and qH is maximum adsorption capacity at equilibrium (mg/g). According to this model, there are three states depending on the value of constant n: n N 1 means positive cooperativity in binding, n = 1 means hyperbolic binding or non-cooperative and n b 1 means negative cooperativity in the binding [51].
Sips isothermor Langmuir-Freundlich isotherm,which has been validated for heterogeneous adsorption processeswithout any reaction between the adsorbent and the adsorbate, is as follows [52]:
qe ¼ qsKsCe
n
1þ KsCen ð14Þ
where qs is maximum adsorption capacity of methyl orange dye and Ks is equilibrium constant of Sips isotherm. If n equals 1, the sips three-parameter isotherm changes into Langmuir two-parameter isotherm. If the isotherm equilibrium constant (Ks) or Ce move towards zero, Sips isotherm becomes Freundlich isotherm.
In 1959, Redlich and Peterson (R-P) proposed a simple design of Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models, with their model being as
follows [53]:
qe ¼ KRPCe
1þ aRCen ð15Þ
where aR and KRP (L/g) are Redlich-Peterson constants and n is the exponent of R-P isothermmodel, which can vary in the 0–1 range. If n= 1, RP equation becomes Langmuir isotherm. Furthermore, at high concentrations, this isotherm is close to Freundlich isotherm. Fig. 9c shows threeparameter isotherms (Hill, Sips and R-P) for the adsorption ofmethyl orange onto the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. Furthermore, the parameters of these isothermmodels alongwith their correlation coefficients are set out in Table 4. A comparison of the correlation coefficients for the different isothermmodel allows concluding that the two-parameter Langmuir isotherm model fits better than the other models to the experimental data.

sections.heading: 3.15. Thermodynamics of methyl orange dye adsorption
sections.text:
Adsorption runs were carried out at 25, 45, 55 and 65 °C in order to study the effect of temperature on the adsorption efficiency of methyl orange dye on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. The results corresponding to different pH values are shown in Table 5. As observed, an increase in the temperature at all pH values led to an increase in the adsorption efficiency of methyl orange. Therefore, methyl orange dye adsorption on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent is endothermic.
The thermodynamic parameters of methyl orange dye adsorption (Gibbs free energy change (ΔG), enthalpy change (ΔH) and entropy change (ΔS)) were calculated based on the results for different temperatures and using Eqs. (16) to (18) [54]:
Kp ¼ γsCsγeCe ð16Þ
ΔG ¼ −RT ln kp ð17Þ
ln kp ¼ −ΔH RT þ ΔS R ð18Þ
where, Cs and Ceare concentration of methyl ornage adsorbed onto nano-adsorbent and its concentration in solution (at equilibrium), respectively. Also, γs is activity coefficient of dye adsorbed onto nano-adsorbent and γe is dye activity coefficient in solution (at equilibrium). T is temperature (Kelvin) and R = 8.314 J/mol·K (the universal gas constant). For Ce→0, activity coefficients (γs and γe) come close unity. So, with assumption of dilute solution, Eq. 16 can changed to Eq. 19 and equilibrium constant can be estimated from this equation:

sections.heading: Kp ¼ CsCe ð19Þ
sections.text: The values of enthalpy and entropy changes for methyl orange dye adsorption were calculated from the slope and intercept of ln(Kp) versus 1T plot. The values are presented in Table 6. As observed, the enthalpy change ofmethyl orange dye adsorption is positive, which indicates that the adsorption process is endothermic. In addition, the negative value of Gibbs free energy change evidences a spontaneousnature of the adsorption process.

sections.heading: 3.16. Comparison between the adsorption capacities of polyaniline nanoadsorbent and other adsorbents
sections.text:
The adsorption capacity of the polyanilinenano-adsorbentwas comparedwith that of other adsorbents and the results are shown in Table 7. The experimental conditions formethyl orange dye adsorption (adsorption time, initial concentration of dye solution, pH and temperature) are also shown in the table for each adsorbent. The adsorption capacity of
the nano-adsorbent used in this study is rather high compared to other studies. Thus, the adsorption capacity reported for Chitosan (CS)/ rectorite (REC)/carbon nanotubes (CNTs) was 50.75 mg/g at the initial concentration of 10–200 mg/g for an adsorption time of 48 h, while in the present study, the nano-adsorbent has an adsorption capacity of 75.9mg/g at the initial concentrations of 10–100mg/L for an adsorption time of 60 min, which is evidence that the polyaniline nano-adsorbent performs well, as it may removemethyl orange dye from aqueous solution in a relatively short time.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: A polyaniline nano-adsorbent was synthesized using the chemical oxidative polymerization technique, and its ability for adsorbingmethyl orange dye from water was studied. The influence of various parameters, namely, adsorption time, mass of adsorbent, solution pH, initial dye concentration and temperature, was studied based on the process simulation by artificial neural network (ANN) model. A comparison of methyl orange dye adsorption efficiencies calculated using ANN model with the experimental data proves that the ANN model can estimate the behavior of themethyl orange dye adsorption process under various experimental conditions. The parameters for two-parameter isotherm models (Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin) and three-parameter isotherm models (Hill, Sips and Redlich-Peterson) have been obtained for methyl orange dye adsorption onto the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. The results are evidence that the experimental data fit best the Langmuir model. The maximum adsorption capacity of the polyaniline nano-adsorbent was 75.9 mg/g. The kinetic study revealed that methyl orange adsorption is controlled by pseudo-second-order kinetics, which is evidence that the process of methyl orange adsorption onto the polyaniline nano-adsorbent is chemisorption in nature. Furthermore, the dye adsorption capacity calculated through the pseudo-secondorder kineticmodel is very close to the experimental value. The thermodynamic studies proved that methyl orange dye adsorption onto the polyaniline nano-adsorbent is endothermic and spontaneous.

The artificial neural network (ANN) is regarded as one of the most powerful tools to predict the adsorption process [30], which is rarely used to model the process of dye adsorption from water and wastewater.

A comparison between the experimental results with the adsorption efficiency predicted by artificial neural networks indicated that the artificial neural network is a suitable predictor to estimate the behavior of methyl orange dye adsorption on gold nanoparticles loaded on activated carbon and Tamarisk under different experimental conditions [31].

Neural network models consist of neurons and weights and they are based on the assumption that a continuous system of simple processing elements can learn complex relationships between independent and dependent variables [32].

It is not easy to develop a neural network model, as it includes the following steps: selection of data, data processing, selection of the neural network structure, selection of network training algorithm, network training, trained neural network testing and using trained neural network for validation and simulation [33].

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 9 August 2017 Received in revised form 28 August 2017 Accepted 30 August 2017 Available online xxxx This study aims to synthesize a polyaniline nano-adsorbent and use it to adsorb methyl orange dye from the aqueous solution. The averageparticle size of nano-adsorbentwas about 70nm. The effects of various parameters have been analysed, as are pH, temperature, adsorption time, initial concentration and adsorbent dosage, and they were optimized by an artificial neural network model. The multilayer feed forward neural network with five inputs and one output has been trained with eight neurons in the hidden layer. A comparison of the experimental datawith the dye adsorption efficiency predicted by the artificial neural networkmodel showed that this model can estimate the behavior of the adsorption process of methyl orange dye on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent under different conditions. The study yielded the result that dye adsorption capacity of the nano-adsorbent increased from 3.34 to 32.04 mg/g and from 3.28 to 30.28 mg/g as the dye initial concentration was increased from 10 to 100 mg/L, at 65 °C and 25 °C, respectively. Also, dye adsorption equilibrium was achieved in 60 min for methyl orange dye. The adsorption kinetics was studied based on pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second-order, intraparticle diffusion and Elovich models. The results showed that the adsorption data at all levels of initial concentration have the best consistency with the pseudo-second order equation. Furthermore, two-parameter isotherm models (Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin) and three-parameter isotherm models (Hill, Sips and R-P) were used to ascertain the nature of the adsorption isotherm. Based on this study, the maximum adsorption capacity was estimated to be 75.9 mg/g. Thermodynamic studies indicated that methyl orange dye adsorption was endothermic on the polyaniline nano-adsorbent. © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
